description.narrative: (i) Funding: IFC will be providing medium/long term funding to support Al-Majmoua''s growth in the microfinance sector in Lebanon and reach out to more of the under served segments of the market. The loan would also assist the MFI to better manage their asset and liability position at the time of limited funding opportunities. (ii) Access to finance: The proposed Project would support Al Majmoua, one of the leading microfinance providers, to expand its outreach and serve a larger number of low-income people in Lebanon. The social impact of the proposed project would be significant especially that women account for 50% of total clients. (iii) Job creation: MSMEs are key contributors to job creation in the Country. Developing a vibrant MSME sector, with reliable access to finance, can play a significant role in private sector led economic growth, generating employment and providing opportunities to the poor and under-served groups. (iv) Demonstration effect: Through this project, IFC is expected to act as a catalyst by encouraging other investors, especially local banks, to fund the microfinance sector and bridge the financing gap facing this sector. Furthermore, and when regulatory environment allows, Al Majmoua will consider/assess transforming from its local NGO status into a financial institution company regulated by the Central Bank. This will be a successful example for other NGOs to strengthen their institutional capacity, implement best standard practices, and to be regulated by the Central Bank.

The project involves a senior loan to the Lebanese Association for Development (Al-Majmoua or the "Organization"). Proceeds of the loan will be used to support Al-Majmouas loan portfolio growth and increase access to funding needs of micro entrepreneurs and low income people in Lebanon, especially women who represent 52% of total clients.
